sen.j: 漢國神社（かんごうじんじゃ）は、奈良県奈良市にある神社である。
sen.e: Kango-jinja Shrine is located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
Kango-jinja Shrine is located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
Kango-jinja Shrine is located in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
The shrine rank in the old system is kensha (shrine taken care of by the prefecture)
The shrine rank in the old system is kensha (shrine taken care of by the prefecture)
The shrine rank in the old system is kensha (shrine taken care of by the prefecture).
Enshrined god
Enshrined god
Enshrined deity

sen.j: 園神として大物主、韓神として大国主・スクナビコナを祀る。
sen.e: Omononnushi is enshrined as Sono-kami (god enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household), and Okuninushi and Sukunabikona are enshrined as Kara-kami (god enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household).

Omononnushi is enshrined as Sono-kami (god enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household), and Okuninushi and Sukunabikona are enshrined as Kara-kami (god enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household).

Omononnushi is enshrined as Sono-kami (god enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household), and Okuninushi and Sukunabikona are enshrined as Kara-kami (god enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household).

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳で宮中宮内省に祀られ名神大社に列すると記される園韓神社は当社からの勧請であると社伝では伝える。
sen.e: The Shrine's history suggests that Sonokara-jinja Shrine, which was enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household and ranked among Myojin taisha-jinja Shrines, according to Engishikijinmeicho, enshrines divided soul of Kango-jinja shrine's god.

The Shrine's history suggests that Sonokara-jinja Shrine, which was enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household and ranked among Myojin taisha-jinja Shrines, according to Engishikijinmeicho, enshrines divided soul of Kango-jinja shrine's god.

History
History
History

sen.j: 推古天皇元年2月3日、勅命により大神君白堤が園神を祀ったのに始まると伝える。
sen.e: On March 12, 593, Omiwanokimi shiratsutsumi enshrined Sono-kami by Imperial order, which was the origin of the shrine.
On March 12, 593, Omiwanokimi shiratsutsumi enshrined Sono-kami by Imperial order, which was the origin of the shrine.
On March 12, 593, Omiwanokimi shiratsutsumi enshrined Sono-kami by Imperial order, which was the origin of the shrine.

sen.j: その後、養老元年11月28日、藤原不比等が韓神二座を相殿として合祀したという。
sen.e: After that, on January 8, 718, FUJIWARA no Fuhito enshrined two Kara-kami together.
After that, on January 8, 718, FUJIWARA no Fuhito enshrined two Kara-kami together.
After that, on January 8, 718, FUJIWARA no Fuhito enshrined two Kara-kami together.

sen.j: かつては春日率川坂岡社と称していたが、韓神の韓が漢に、園神の園が國となり、「漢國神社」という社名になったと伝える。
sen.e: It is said that in the past, it was named Kasuga izakawazakaokasha, but it turned to be 'Kango-jinja Shrine', making kan (韓) in kara-kami kan (漢) and sono (園) in sono-kami go (國).
It is said that in the past, it was named Kasuga izakawazakaokasha, but it turned to be 'Kango-jinja Shrine', making kan (韓) in kara-kami kan (漢) and sono (園) in sono-kami go (國).
It is said that in the past, it was named Kasuga izakawazakaokasha, but it turned to be 'Kango-jinja Shrine,' making kan (韓) in kara-kami kan (漢) and sono (園) in sono-kami go (國).

sen.j: 貞観 (日本)元年1月27日、平安京内の宮内省に当社の祭神を勧請し、皇室の守護神としたと社伝では伝えているが、平安京の園神社・韓神社の社伝とは矛盾している。
sen.e: The shrine history shows that on March 9, 859, the divided soul of the god enshrined in this shrine was enshrined in the Ministry of the Imperial Household within Heian-kyo to make it the god protecting the Imperial family, but this discription contradicts the shrine history of sono-jinja Shrine and Kara-jinja Shrine in Heian-kyo.

Facilities
Facilities
Facilities
Rin-jinja Shrine
Rin-jinja Shrine
Rin-jinja Shrine

sen.j: 境内社の林神社（りんじんじゃ）は、林浄因命を祀り、日本唯一の饅頭の神社として製菓業者の信仰を集めている。
sen.e: Rin-jinja Shrine located in the precincts of Kango-jinja Shrine enshrines Rinjoin no mikoto and attracts believers of confectioners as the only shrine of steamed buns.
Rin-jinja Shrine located in the precincts of Kango-jinja Shrine enshrines Rinjoin no mikoto and attracts confectioners as the only shrine of steamed buns.
Rin-jinja Shrine located in the precincts of Kango-jinja Shrine enshrines Rinjoin no mikoto and attracts confectioners as the only shrine of steamed buns.

sen.j: 林浄因は現在の中国・浙江省杭州市出身で、貞和5年に来日し、漢国神社社頭に住居して日本初となる饅頭を作ったという。
sen.e: Rinjoin was from Hangzhou, Zheijiang Province, China, came to Japan in 1349, lived in front of the buildings of Kango-jinja Shrine and made steamed bun for the first time in Japan.
Rinjoin was from Hangzhou, Zheijiang Province, China, came to Japan in 1349, lived in front of the buildings of Kango-jinja Shrine and made steamed buns for the first time in Japan.
